title: Introduction
Introduction
text:
Topic 2

Exercise with Hint
Here’s an exercise where the chunk is pre-evaluated via the exercise.eval option (so the user can see the default output we’d like them to customize). We also add a “hint” to the correct solution via the chunk immediate below labeled print-limit-hint.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Welcome all!
Today’s aims:

Provide a broad overview of context-specific modelling
Site files: how to characterise a setting
Introduce the malariaverse packages to support 📦 malariasimulation modelling
Exercises:

Running a site
Calibrating a site
Dealing with bed nets

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Modelling philosophy
One common dichotomisation is between:

Generic modelling

Run the model for generic settings (e.g. Low/Medium/High PfPr2-10)
Allows precise exploration of model behaviour and intervention impact in controlled in silico environment
Can be challenging to translate general results
e.g. Modelling population-level impact to inform target product profiles for childhood malaria vaccines. Hogan et al BMC Medicine, 2018.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Modelling philosophy
One common dichotomisation is between:

Context-specific modelling

Run the model for a specific setting/location
Can be used to informs policy and impact assessment for specific areas
Requires “the context” to be adequately captured
e.g. Estimated impact of RTS,S/AS01 malaria vaccine allocation strategies in sub-Saharan Africa: A modelling study Hogan et al PLoS Medicine, 2020.

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Important features

Intrinsic transmission potential (“Baseline”, “Carrying capacity”, “R0”)
The mosquito vector

species
bionomics & behaviour
distribution & relative abundance
insecticide resistance

Rainfall seasonality
Historical interventions
Epidemiological data
Human population & demography

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Site files

Historically, the group has collected the required information to characterise a setting into a “Site file”.
We have tried to formalise this approach in malariaverse
The 📦 foresite package contains our first-pass attempt at site-files for all countries
They contains estimates for all of the important features needed to characterise a site
The foresite website contains detailed information about each element of a site file

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Site files

library(foresite)
head(TGO$prevalence)

  country iso3c name_1 urban_rural year      pfpr pvpr
1    Togo   TGO Centre       rural 2000 0.6052841    0
2    Togo   TGO Centre       rural 2001 0.5733003    0
3    Togo   TGO Centre       rural 2002 0.5585785    0
4    Togo   TGO Centre       rural 2003 0.5469875    0
5    Togo   TGO Centre       rural 2004 0.5521835    0
6    Togo   TGO Centre       rural 2005 0.5470634    0

head(TGO$interventions[,3:8])

  name_1 urban_rural year    itn_use itn_input_dist        net_type
1 Centre       rural 2000 0.04239319   3.972372e-02 pyrethroid_only
2 Centre       rural 2001 0.03059912   1.999607e-03 pyrethroid_only
3 Centre       rural 2002 0.02194407   1.225237e-05 pyrethroid_only
4 Centre       rural 2003 0.02110716   3.579113e-03 pyrethroid_only
5 Centre       rural 2004 0.14395837   1.402791e-01 pyrethroid_only
6 Centre       rural 2005 0.20412837   9.050257e-02 pyrethroid_only

title: Malariaverse Workshop Introduction
text:
Running a site

We can use another malariaverse 📦 site to translate the site file information into 📦 malariasimulation parameter input.


# Isolate a single site from a country
example_site <- site::single_site(foresite::TGO, 1)
# Create parameter inputs
site_pars <- site::site_parameters(
  interventions = example_site$interventions,
  demography = example_site$demography,
  vectors = example_site$vectors,
  seasonality = example_site$seasonality,
  eir = example_site$eir$eir[1],
  overrides = list(human_population = 10000)
)
# Run!
model_run <- malariasimulation::run_simulation(timesteps = site_pars$timesteps,
                                               parameters = site_pars)

text:
